item.title: Live Updates: Zelensky Says His Request for Tomahawks Is Still ‘Under Discussion’ With Trump
item.description: Zelensky wants long-range missiles that could reach far into Russia, which Putin opposes. After meeting with Zelensky, Trump said he told both the Ukrainian and Russian leaders that it was “time to stop the killing.”

item.title: Zelensky to Meet With Trump to Discuss Weapons and Peace Prospects for Ukraine
item.description: President Trump said he wanted Ukraine and Russia to stop fighting and was hesitant about providing President Volodymyr Zelensky with long-range missiles.

item.title: Despite Gaza Cease-Fire, Aid Deliveries Struggle
item.description: A single photograph of Palestinians besieging an aid convoy after the new cease-fire took hold in Gaza makes clear how much work lies ahead in the enclave.

item.title: Tomiichi Murayama, Japanese Leader Who Gave Landmark War Apology, Dies at 101
item.description: His televised address as prime minister, delivered 50 years to the day after Japan announced its surrender, set a marker for his country’s “deep remorse” over wartime atrocities.

item.title: Iran Extends Internet Clampdown Beyond Wartime
item.description: Since its brief June war with Israel, Iran has throttled internet traffic and jammed GPS, making day-to-day tasks online a struggle and prompting Iranians’ fears of greater surveillance.

item.title: After ‘Horrors,’ Israeli Hostages Taste Freedom and Savor Family Reunions
item.description: Some former captives have been sent home from the hospital. But a doctor said they all had “endured untold adversity,” as details emerge of their time in Gaza’s tunnels.

item.title: Prince Andrew Surrenders Duke of York Title Amid Epstein Fallout
item.description: The royal’s fall from grace began nearly six years ago with a calamitous BBC television interview about his ties to the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force in the Caribbean
item.description: About 10,000 U.S. troops and dozens of military aircraft and ships are in the region as the Trump administration increases pressure on Venezuela.

item.title: Machado’s Nobel Peace Prize Brings Hope and Scrutiny to Venezuela’s Opposition
item.description: Ms. Machado’s efforts to reclaim a stolen election by any available means, including military intervention, has long galvanized her supporters. Her opponents say these hard-line policies have a political cost.

item.title: Meet the Designer Who Got Zelensky Into a Suit
item.description: Viktor Anisimov, one of Ukraine’s top fashion designers, first met Volodymyr Zelensky about 20 years ago, when the future president was a comedian. He didn’t want to wear a suit then either.

item.title: Madagascar’s President Was Ousted After Youth Protests. Now What?
item.description: The young people who toppled the government are now confronting questions about what’s next, and who will deliver on their demands.

item.title: Starmer Objects as Police Bar Israeli Team’s Fans From U.K. Soccer Game
item.description: Confrontation has shadowed Israeli teams’ games in Europe since the start of the Gaza war. Local authorities sought to bar visiting fans at a game in central England next month.

item.title: Devastating Floods in Mexico Test President Claudia Sheinbaum
item.description: Torrential rains last week brought death and widespread damage. President Claudia Sheinbaum has visited affected areas, facing some angry residents.

item.title: Bessent Stakes Credibility and Taxpayer Money on Argentina Bet
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent’s multibillion-dollar bailout of a serial defaulter raises the specter of losses for the United States.

item.title: How a U.K. Spy Case Against China Abruptly Fell Apart
item.description: Evidence prepared for a collapsed espionage trial was published by an under-pressure government in Britain, offering a window into Western countries’ struggle to define Beijing as friend or foe.

item.title: Chevron Thrives in Venezuela Despite Threats by Trump
item.description: Chevron enjoys unusual sway in socialist-led Venezuela, positioning the energy colossus to gain from whatever comes of the crisis between Washington and Caracas.

item.title: Teresa Ulloa Ziáurriz, Rights Advocate Who Fought Sex Traffickers, Dies at 75
item.description: In Mexico, where the cult of machismo has long held sway, she waged a lonely, sometimes dangerous and often single-handed fight against prostitution and organized sex rings.

item.title: Oscar Wilde Gets His Library Card Back, 125 Years After His Death
item.description: The Irish writer was barred in 1895 after being convicted of gross indecency. On Thursday, the British Library will hand over a symbolic new card to his grandson.

item.title: U.S. Pressures Countries to Delay Fees to Clean Up Ship Pollution
item.description: Under threats of tariffs and other sanctions from the U.S., nations postponed a vote on whether to charge fees on emissions from ships.

item.title: What to Know About Madagascar’s Government
item.description: After weeks of protests calling for him to resign, Madagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, seemed to have left the country, and the military said it had taken control. John Eligon, the Johannesburg bureau chief for The New York Times, explains what we know and don’t know.

item.title: Russia Jails Street Band for Performing Antiwar Songs
item.description: The group, called Stoptime, had been performing anti-Kremlin songs for months and gaining in popularity before the authorities moved against the open dissent.

item.title: Putin Plays to Trump’s Ego as U.S. Wavers on Ukraine Aid
item.description: After Thursday’s phone call with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Trump appeared to express doubts about supplying Ukraine with more powerful weapons.

item.title: Funeral Is Held for Raila Odinga, a Pillar of Kenya’s Democracy
item.description: Thousands paid their respects at a stadium in Nairobi. President William Ruto said the spirit of Mr. Odinga, who died at 80, “lives within every Kenyan and every African.”

item.title: Trump Warns Hamas of Strikes if Violence in Gaza Continues
item.description: The president later clarified that the United States would not be involved in such an action.

item.title: OpenAI Blocks Videos of Martin Luther King Jr. After Racist Depictions
item.description: People have used its Sora video app to create vulgar and sometimes racist depictions of the civil rights leader.

item.title: China Ousts Senior General on Corruption Charges
item.description: With the fall of He Weidong, the No. 3 figure in China’s military hierarchy, Xi Jinping’s purges have reached the top of the People’s Liberation Army.

item.title: Explosion Destroys Vehicles Outside Home of Italian Journalist
item.description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni condemned the attack on Sigfrido Ranucci, the host of the investigative program “Report.”

item.title: A History of the C.I.A.’s Involvement in Latin America, From Bay of Pigs to Chile Coups
item.description: For much of the 20th century, the C.I.A. devised plots to overthrow governments, kill high-profile leaders or arm dissident groups.

item.title: Vivienne Westwood Show Opens Riyadh Fashion Week, as Saudis Highlight Creative Side
item.description: Some Saudis see the provocative brand’s appearance as one more example of the kingdom’s pursuit of cultural cachet. But some critics see incongruity in such pairings.

item.title: Save the Whales. But Save the Microbes, Too.
item.description: Conservation biologists propose a daunting task: protecting Earth’s diversity of bacteria and other microbes.

item.title: Kanchha Sherpa, Last Member of First Team to Conquer Everest, Dies at 92
item.description: A trip to India to find work led to a career climbing the world’s highest mountain.

item.title: After ‘Productive’ Call, Trump Plans Another Meeting With Putin
item.description: President Trump has come close to imposing penalties on Russia several times, only to backtrack after talking with President Vladimir Putin and raising hopes for a diplomatic solution to the war.

item.title: How to Live a Long and Healthy Life as an Introvert
item.description: Our personal health reporter explains why it’s the quality, not quantity, of socializing that matters.

item.title: How Raila Odinga Symbolized the Good and Bad of Kenyan Politics
item.description: He was one of the most pivotal public figures in Kenya. He died this week after fighting against tribalism for decades.

item.title: U.S. Military Killed Venezuelan Fisherman in Suspected Drug Boat Attack, Family Says
item.description: For the first time, one of the 27 people killed in U.S. airstrikes on suspected drug vessels has been publicly identified.

item.title: 2 Dead After Kenyan Police Fire Bullets at Raila Odinga Memorial
item.description: The deadly tumult was the latest example of officers using force to quell demonstrations in the country.

item.title: What’s Next for the Gaza Cease-Fire Plan
item.description: Israel and Hamas have reached a cease-fire deal in Gaza, but the hard part starts now. David Sanger of The New York Times describes the major obstacles to further agreement about Gaza’s immediate future.

item.title: Where Does the Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Stand?
item.description: Unresolved issues — mainly over the exchange of the remains of hostages and prisoners — threaten to destabilize the fragile agreement.

item.title: Fire in Party Office Raises Tensions as Cameroon Awaits Election Results
item.description: The blaze and arrests of protesters highlight the strife in the country, whose longtime president faced rare electoral opposition.

item.title: Guatemala Welcomes U.S. Help in Gang Crackdown After Prison Break
item.description: President Bernardo Arévalo called an overhaul of his country’s prison system an “absolute priority” after 20 inmates accused of belonging to the Barrio 18 group were found to have escaped undetected.

item.title: Vatican Panel Says Church Is Still Too Slow in Addressing Sexual Abuse
item.description: The commission’s report highlights the difficulties Pope Leo faces in trying to end clerical abuses and ensure abusers are held to account.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthis Confirm Killing of Top Military Official
item.description: It was unclear when Maj. Gen. Mohammed al-Ghomari was killed, or by whom, but Israel appeared to claim the killing.

item.title: Russia Is Arming Drones With North Korean Cluster Weapons, Report Says
item.description: Though Pyongyang has largely pulled its soldiers off the front lines in Ukraine, it is expanding the types of ammunition it supplies to Russia.

item.title: World Meteorological Report Marks Biggest Annual Jump in CO2 Levels
item.description: Surging emissions from wildfires may have been behind the increase, which was the largest since modern measurements began more than half a century ago.

item.title: Judge Throws Out Children’s Lawsuit Against Trump’s Energy Policies
item.description: The group had challenged the president’s executive orders as unconstitutional. A judge “reluctantly” said the suit was too broad in scope.

item.title: Trump Considers Overhaul of Refugee System That Would Favor White People
item.description: The proposals would transform a program aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the world into one that gives preference to mostly white people who say they are being persecuted.

item.title: Israel Marks Two Years Since Oct. 7 as a Fragile Cease-Fire in Gaza Holds
item.description: Ceremonies took place on Thursday to commemorate two years since the surprise attack of Oct. 7, 2023, on southern Israel.

item.title: How Assad’s Top Henchmen Fled Syria and Justice
item.description: As Syria’s regime collapsed, the world’s eyes were on Bashar al-Assad’s getaway flight. Behind him, officials key to his brutal rule made a mass exodus, virtually undetected.

item.title: France’s Government Narrowly Survives No-Confidence Vote
item.description: The result gives Sébastien Lecornu, France’s prime minister, a reprieve after weeks of political turmoil. But he still has to get a budget passed by the end of the year.

item.title: India Tiptoes Around Trump’s Latest Claims on Russian Oil Purchases
item.description: The government subtly rebuffed the president’s comments that it would stop buying Russian oil, as it tries to avoid a public fight and end a trade dispute with Washington.

item.title: China Fans Patriotic Sentiment as Trade War With U.S. Heats Up
item.description: Chinese state media is rallying the public and posting old propaganda footage, but officials are also careful to leave room for talks with President Trump.

item.title: Armed With Anemones: How Some Young Fish Survive in the Sea
item.description: Photos taken by blackwater divers offered a new glimpse into the early life stages of marine fishes and their interactions with other animals.

item.title: Inside the Reporting on Assad’s Top Officials Who Fled Syria
item.description: New York Times reporters compiled a wide array of clues to uncover what happened to Bashar al-Assad’s key enforcers after the fall of the regime.

item.title: Trump Administration Authorizes Covert C.I.A. Action in Venezuela
item.description: The development comes as the U.S. military is drawing up options for President Trump to consider, including possible strikes inside the country.

item.title: China’s Own Immigration Backlash
item.description: The response to a new visa for skilled foreign workers has caught even the Chinese government by surprise.

item.title: Hamas Says It Has Returned All Hostage Remains It Can Recover
item.description: The militants said they would need special equipment to retrieve more bodies in Gaza. The announcement could put the truce with Israel at risk.

item.title: Trump Helped Argentina Face an Economic Meltdown. It Came At a Cost.
item.description: When President Javier Milei of Argentina faced an economic meltdown, President Trump vowed to come to his aid. But that lifeline is coming at a cost.
